DataElement.preferredName: Genetically Modified Autologous Lymphocyte Infusion Occurrence Date
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The calendar date of an infusion of genetically modified autologous lymphocytes into a patient.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Genetically Modified Autologous Lymphocyte Infusion Occurrence
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The technology of preparing recombinant DNA in vitro by cutting up DNA molecules and splicing together fragments from more than one organism._The technology of preparing recombinant DNA in vitro by cutting up DNA molecules and splicing together fragments from more than one organism._Taken from an individual's own tissues, cells, or DNA._White blood cells formed in the body's lymphoid tissue. The nucleus is round or ovoid with coarse, irregularly clumped chromatin while the cytoplasm is typically pale blue with azurophilic (if any) granules. Most lymphocytes can be classified as either T or B (with subpopulations of each); those with characteristics of neither major class are called null cells._A method of putting fluids, including drugs, into the bloodstream._An instance of something happening, such as an event or incident.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The technology of preparing recombinant DNA in vitro by cutting up DNA molecules and splicing together fragments from more than one organism.:Taken from an individual's own tissues, cells, or DNA.:A type of immune cell that is made in the bone marrow and is found in the blood and in lymph tissue. The two main types of lymphocytes are B lymphocytes and T lymphocytes. B lymphocytes make antibodies, and T lymphocytes help kill tumor cells and help control immune responses. A lymphocyte is a type of white blood cell.

Concepts.definition: The application of genetic-based biotechnology to modify the characteristics of an organism by cutting, splicing, and transferring genetic materials, especially DNA, from one or more species of organism.
Taken from an individual's own tissues, cells, or DNA.

White blood cells formed in the body's lymphoid tissue. The nucleus is round or ovoid with coarse, irregularly clumped chromatin while the cytoplasm is typically pale blue with azurophilic (if any) granules. Most lymphocytes can be classified as either T or B (with subpopulations of each); those with characteristics of neither major class are called null cells.

Property.preferredDefinition: A method of putting fluids, including drugs, into the bloodstream.:An instance of something happening, such as an event or incident.

Concepts.definition: Any form of treatment that is introduced into the body via a blood vessel, a muscle, or the spinal cord.
An instance of something happening, such as an event or incident.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: actions or administration of therapeutic agents to produce an effect that is intended to alter the course of a pathologic process (NCI).

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: a particular day specified as the time something has, or will, happen.

Concepts.definition: The particular day, month and year an event has happened or will happen.
